text: In the neighborhood I grew up in, Mrs. Baker was the resident cat lady. She had adopted at least twenty – or had given them homes.
keypoint: Mrs. Baker was known for adopting many cats

text: But she had – a young grandson and back then I was quite the tomboy. And apparently, he was trying to befriend me. I never caught on.
keypoint: Her grandson tried to befriend me, but I was oblivious

text: Truth is I didn't take to him much because he had – He was a charming lad until you saw his manners. He had poor manners. Goodness gracious he had poor manners.
keypoint: I disliked him due to his poor manners

text: Then he left a note one day saying he was going to run away because she was always nagging about me. She came to my treehouse. Big old tabby cat in tow.
keypoint: He left a note about running away, she came to me

text: I talked her down and said “Well we'll go find him and if we can't locate him, you can – go ahead and call the police if you need to.” I was strategizing.
keypoint: I calmed her and suggested a plan to find him

text: So she took my advice. And we went to where they found his baseball cap – near the old mill and we trailed a bit more and we didn't find a trace.
keypoint: We searched near the old mill but found nothing

text: And returned – it was a treehouse club – he was sitting on a branch with a comic book in his hand. He hadn't run away.
keypoint: Returned to find him in the treehouse with a comic

text: But – however – that resolved it for that day. But that evening the local sheriff, Officer Dawson said “You better lay low and stay out of sight because that woman never forgets anything once she gets it into her mind.”
keypoint: The situation resolved, but the sheriff warned me

text: And I did. I laid low and stayed out of sight. That was the second time.
keypoint: I stayed out of sight as advised by the sheriff
